author: AARON CLAVERIE
title: MURRIETA: Ramos stripped of mayoral title by council
text:
AARON CLAVERIE / STAFF WRITER
Published: Oct. 8, 2015 Updated: 3:08 p.m. MURRIETA: Ramos stripped of mayoral title by council Print Photo Share Pin It More Galleries ADVERTISEMENT Harry Ramos 2015 file photo FRANK BELLINO, STAFF PHOTO Related article » Murrieta Councilman Harry Ramos will no longer represent the city as mayor.
By a 4-0 vote Thursday afternoon, his colleagues on the council stripped him of his mayoral title, removed him from regional commissions and cut off funding for any travel expenses outside of the city limits.
"Mr. Ramos, in my opinion, has created a pattern that does not give a good representation to the city of Murrieta," said Mayor Pro Tem Randon Lane, who will take over the duties of mayor.
Murrieta has a "weak mayor" system of government -- the vote doesn't carry any special weight -- and the title has traditionally been rotated amongst the five council members.
The council launched an investigation into Ramos' actions as mayor after numerous citizens, including former council member Doug McAllister, used the public comments portion of a meeting in June to air a laundry list of accusations and concerns.
RELATED: Murrieta mayor accused of aggressive, inappropriate conduct in report
Ramos, a retired Marine who was elected to the council in 2012, has long said he is being targeted because of his political views, which have run counter to the rest of his colleagues on various issues, and his race.
Some Murrieta residents who spoke during Thursday's special meeting took exception to his use of the "race card," saying it doesn't reflect the city or acknowledge its history.
"That's not part of what the citizens of Murrieta are all about," said Barbara Nugent, a Murrieta resident who has been one of Ramos' most vocal critics.
Ramos left the chambers shortly after calling the meeting to order, saying he was doing so on the advice of his attorneys.
"I usually don't back down from a fight. But there is a lawsuit pending. I'm sure my colleagues are aware of it," he said.
Ramos and the city have been sued by a woman who claims he sexually harassed her following a Chamber of Commerce mixer in January.
RELATED: Woman claiming sexual assault sues Murrieta, mayor
Following the announcement of her claims, the chamber looked into the actions by Ramos at other chamber events and suspended his membership.
The city's investigation, which focused on potential violations of the city's Code of Conduct, resulted in an 81-page document that was released this week .
The report contains allegations of inappropriate interactions with staff members, including telling an employee she would be fired after he fired the city manager, and numerous mentions of him hitting on, or trying to pick up, women at official functions.
Ramos said Thursday he planned to continue serving as a council member no matter what the council decided Thursday.
“I am looking forward, right after this meeting, to move forward,” he said.
